wikipedia_page.main: Grace McDougall or Grace Alexandra Smith or Grace Ashley-Smith (1887 – 1963) was a British officer of the First Aid Nursing Yeomanry (FANY). She is credited with reinventing that organisation and with being the first khaki bride. She gained British, French and Belgian medals.

response: Early leaders of the FANY included Grace McDougall and Lilian Franklin, "The Boss".
Sgt Major Grace McDougall was said to be the first bride to marry whilst wearing khaki at her wedding here on 22 January 1915.
* Grace McDougall, leader of the First Aid Nursing Yeomanry

Grace McDougall (1887–1963) was the energetic commandant of the First Aid Nursing Yeomanry (FANY), which had formed in 1907 as an auxiliary to the home guard in Britain. McDougall at one point was captured by the Germans but escaped. The British army wanted nothing to do with them so they drove ambulances and ran hospitals and casualty clearing stations for the Belgian and French armies.Roy Terry, "McDougall, Grace Alexandra (1887–1963)", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, (2004); online edn, May 2006 accessed 6 March 2013Janet Lee, "A Nurse and a Soldier: Gender, Class and National Identity in the First World War Adventures of Grace McDougall and Flora Sandes," Women's History Review (2006) 15#1 pp. 83–103; Janet Lee, War girls: the First Aid Nursing Yeomanry in the First World War (Manchester University Press, 2012)

Ellis was awarded a medal in 1918 by the Queen of Belgium for her service during World War I.  The FANYs in Belgium were reluctant to leave their life together and return home in 1919. Their commander Grace McDougall's decision was made for her because her mother was dangerously ill so she had to return. It fell to Ellis to demobilize the FANY's and send them "back to blighty". The decision was made after seeing soldier/mechanics returning from the war and unable to get work. It was felt that men should have the jobs.
